title: Trump safe after gunshots, 'apparent assassination attempt' at his golf club, Biden and Harris 'relieved'
summary: FBI says former president Donald Trump was subject of 'an apparent assassination attempt.' US Secret Service agents opened fire after seeing a person with a firearm near Donald Trump’s golf club while the Republican presidential candidate was golfing Sunday. Martin County Sheriff William D. Snyder said the suspect was apprehended within minutes of the FBI, Secret Service and Palm Beach County Sheriff’s Office putting out an urgent 'be on the lookout' alert.

title: France cultivates ambiguity over deep strikes in Russia
summary: The Ukrainians want to disrupt Russian logistics at the rear of the front line.

title: 2024 US election: Donald Trump's strange strategy of ignoring moderates
summary: The Republican candidate, more used to a golf cart than a shopping cart, didn't exploit economic issues in the televised debate against Kamala Harris, who adopted a calm, centrist line, designed to appeal to undecided voters neglected by her opponent.

title: The bloody repression of pacifist opposition to colonization in the West Bank
summary: IIn the West Bank, Palestinian militias benefit from Israel's brutal repression of non-violent opposition to settlement.

title: French mass rape trial: What exactly is 'chemical submission'?
summary: The use of drugs to perpetrate sexual assaults has been on the rise over the past 20 years, according to the National Agency for Medicine Safety (ANSM).

title: When sexual identities are not set in stone
summary: Our sexuality isn't as well defined as we might think, notes Le Monde sex columnist Maïa Mazaurette, who urges us not to get pigeonholed into overly precise categories.

title: 'Current events in Germany show that there is no miracle solution when it comes to migration policy'
summary: Germany's change of course regarding the welcoming of foreigners seems neither totally credible nor realistic, and ends up strengthening the far-right, analyzed law professors Anne Jacquemet-Gauché and Nils Schaks in an article for 'Le Monde.'

title: Paris bids farewell to Olympics with Champs-Elysées parade: 'It's a bit hard that it's all over'
summary: The French athletes' and volunteers' parade prolonged, for one final night, the excitement seen during the Olympic and Paralympic Games.

title: Between France and Algeria, an enduring cycle of conflict
summary: Algiers and Paris are in conflict once again, for the third time in three years, highlighting the recurring turbulence in the relationship between the two countries.

title: 'We are all Gisèle!': Feminists rally across France in response to mass rape trial
summary: Across France on Saturday, thousands of people showed their support for Gisèle Pelicot and all rape victims. 'Shame must change sides,' was their slogan.

title: Typhoon Bebinca strikes Philippines, Japan, and soon China
summary: The tropical storm, with windspeeds over 198 kilometers per hour, has led to several deaths in the Philippines areas of Malabang and Zamboanga, as well as displacing around 13,000 people. All flights at Shanghai's two major airports have been canceled.

title: Germany's toughening on immigration sparks tense debate in Europe
summary: Germany has decided to re-establish border controls and has deported Afghan immigrants. While some EU member states have criticized it for going it alone, supporters of the 'Fortress Europe' idea have welcomed the policy change.

title: China resolves to raise retirement age
summary: The Chinese will have to work between three and five years longer. In a sign of the sensitivity of the subject, the reform will go into effect very gradually.

title: In the Los Angeles area, authorities rush to fight Bridge Fire: 'This fire is really bad'
summary: In just a few days, three major wildfires broke out within a radius of less than 100 kilometers around the metropolitan area, fanned by a drought that is taking its toll on abundant vegetation.

title: Storm Boris rages on in eastern and central Europe
summary: The storm, now in its second day, has triggered floods, unusually strong winds and torrential rains across areas of Austria, Hungary and Slovakia, as well as leading to deaths and disappearances in Romania, Poland, and the Czech Republic.

title: Eight migrants die trying to cross Channel, say French authorities
summary: Authorities said numerous attempts to make the crossing have taken place in recent days. Two weeks ago, 12 people died in a similar disaster.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote JK Rowling
summary: In recent years, the British author has gone from creating Harry Potter to making repeated transphobic remarks, including attacking sprinter Valentina Petrillo during the Paralympics. The novelist's name first appeared in Le Monde on January 29, 1999.

title: In Argentina, the controversial launch of a biopic praising Javier Milei
summary: The director of the six-part series chronicling the Argentine president's career, elected in November 2023, is also the director of audiovisual productions for the presidency and the government. It is an openly calculated 'propaganda film.'

title: Emmy Awards honor the best of TV with father-son hosts Eugene and Dan Levy, 'The Bear' and 'Baby Reindeer' lead the way
summary: 'The Bear' romps with four wins including best actor in a comedy at the 76th Emmy Awards in Los Angeles.

title: 'To reduce their environmental impact, why not simply regulate the weight of cars?'
summary: New European standards will make vehicles even heavier and more polluting, both in terms of construction and usage, with questionable effects on road safety, writes Le Monde columnist Stéphane Foucart.

title: Syria's youth and the temptation of leaving
summary: 'Syrian Diaires' (Part 2/7): Economic stagnation and the fear of conscription have led most Syrian students, a truly lost generation, to look for ways to leave their country.

title: Death toll rises as torrential rain and flooding force evacuations in Central Europe
summary: The floods have claimed six lives in Romania and one each in Austria and Poland. In the Czech Republic, four people who were swept away by waters were missing, police said.

title: Shanghai hit by strongest typhoon since 1949
summary: Bebinca made landfall early Monday morning after more than 400,000 people were evacuated.

title: 10 stunning fashion exhibitions for a stylish fall
summary: With haute couture hats at the Palais Galliera, inspiring flowers at the Musée Yves Saint Laurent and photos by Peter Lindbergh at La Galerie Dior, there are so many pieces to admire to usher in fall in style.

title: In Japan, a Korean anthem doesn't go down well
summary: The victory of Kyoto International High School, a school to educate the children of Korean expatriates, in the national high school baseball tournament has prompted a wave of criticism from the country's nationalist fringe.

title: Apparent assassination attempt against Trump once again disrupts US election campaign
summary: A suspect was arrested after a security agent saw the barrel of a gun pointed toward a golf course where former president and candidate Donald Trump was playing with a friend.

title: European Commissioner Thierry Breton resigns amid dispute with von der Leyen
summary: In his resignation letter, the French commissioner accused the Commission chief, who is in the process of forming the new EU's executive branch, of trying to get Emmanuel Macron to withdraw his name from candidacy.

title: Tito Jackson, member of the Jackson 5, has died at 70
summary: Born on October 15, 1953, Toriano Adaryll "Tito" Jackson was a background singer and guitarist in the Jackson 5, with his brother Michael achieving global fame as the King of Pop.

title: Small boat shipwrecks continue in the English Channel
summary: Eight men died on Sunday as they tried to reach England in a dinghy. 2024 is the deadliest year since these increasingly overcrowded migrant boats began crossing the Channel.

title: France nominates foreign minister Stéphane Séjourné for EU Commission
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has proposed outgoing Foreign Affairs Minister Stéphane Séjourné as a European Commissioner following the resignation of the EU Commissioner for Internal Market Thierry Breton.

title: Jihadist tried for his role in recruiting January 2015 Paris terrorist
summary: Peter Cherif, who spent seven years in Yemen in the ranks of al-Qaeda, is on trial for terrorism charges from Monday before the Paris Special Criminal Court.

title: 'After the success of the Paralympics, the question of disability must be considered in terms of equal rights'
summary: A simple 'change of perception' will not be sufficient to promote the inclusion of people with disabilities. Non-disabled people must also be expected to change their habits, says Philippe Bernard.

title: Shogun: The Japanese-American series that made Emmy Awards history
summary: After being dominated for several years by 'Succession' and 'Ted Lasso', this year's awards honored a number of robust series, as well as some more surprising choices.

title: Barcelona property owners organize against tourist rental ban
summary: An association of rental property owners is threatening the Catalan government with multiple legal actions against a new law that has enabled Barcelona's Socialist mayor to ban Airbnb and similar platforms by the end of 2028.

title: 'For those stranded in Calais, the border is not a sieve but, all too often, a death trap'
summary: After French PM Michel Barnier described his desire to 'control migratory flows,' public law professor Thibaut Fleury Graff draws attention to the measures taken to deny access to French territory.

title: Taliban suspends polio vaccinations in Afghanistan, UN reports
summary: Afghanistan and Pakistan are the two countries in which the spread of the potentially fatal, paralyzing disease has never been stopped. No reason was given for the suspension.

title: 'From this side of the Atlantic, Trump can seem like an anomaly, but he has taken the measure of a profound American anxiety'
summary: Le Monde's former correspondent in Washington, Gilles Paris, answered readers' questions after an apparent second assassination attempt targeted Trump on Sunday.

title: Jewish Chronicle columnists resign over allegations Gaza articles were fabricated
summary: Jonathan Freedland, Hadley Freeman and David Aaronovitch resigned after articles by the newspaper's freelance journalist, Elon Perry, falsely alleged that Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar planned to smuggle himself and Israeli hostages out of Gaza through the border area with Egypt.

title: Ex-BBC anchor Huw Edwards avoids jail over 'repugnant' child images
summary: The 63-year-old presenter was handed a six-month sentence, suspended for two years, after admitting to receiving 41 indecent images of children over WhatsApp.

title: Manchester City's 'trial of the century' opens in England
summary: The Mancunian club is facing 115 charges before a Premier League committee for breaching UEFA's financial fair play rules between 2009 and 2018.

title: UK PM Starmer praises Italy's Meloni for reducing illegal migration
summary: Keir Starmer's visit came a day after eigh people died in the latest migrant shipwreck in the Channel.

title: Storm Boris unleashes massive flooding across central Europe
summary: Poland and Romania have been among the hardest hit countries after Storm Boris unleashed huge amounts of rain.

title: Suspect in Trump apparent assassination attempt charged with gun crimes
summary: Fifty-eight-year-old Ryan Wesley Routh, who was arrested on Sunday after an alleged abortive bid to shoot the former president at his West Palm Beach golf course, is expected to face further charges at a later arraignment.
